Kim Hye-sook(daughter,1961) |blank1 = Religion |data1 = [[Presbyterianism]] ([[Presbyterian Church in Korea (HapDong)|GAPCK]]) |signature = Kim Young-Sam signature.svg |allegiance={{flag|South Korea|1949}} |branch= {{flagicon image|Flag_of_the_Army_of_the_Republic_of_Korea.svg|size=23px}} [[Republic of Korea Army]] |rank= [[Officer candidate|Student soldier]] |footnotes = | module = {{Infobox Korean name |tablewidth = 265 |color = lavender |title = [[Korean name]] |hangul = {{linktext|김|영|삼}} |hanja = {{linktext|金|泳|三|}} |rr = Gim Yeongsam |mr = Kim Yŏngsam |hangulho={{linktext|거|산}} |hanjaho={{linktext|巨|山|}} |rrho=Geosan |mrho=Kŏsan | child = yes}} }} '''Kim Young-sam''' ({{korean|hangul=김영삼|hanja=金泳三}}; {{IPA-ko|ki.mjʌŋ.sam}} or {{IPA-ko|kim|}} {{IPA-ko|jʌŋ.sam|}}; 20 December 1927 – 22 November 2015) was a [[South Korea]]n politician and democratic activist, who served as [[President of South Korea]] from 1993 to 1998. From 1961, he spent almost 30 years as one of the leaders of the South Korean opposition, and one of the most powerful rivals to the authoritarian regimes of [[Park Chung-hee]] and [[Chun Doo-hwan]]. Elected president in 1992, Kim became the first civilian to hold the office in over 30 years. He was inaugurated on 25 February 1993, and served a single five-year term, presiding over a massive anti-corruption campaign, the arrest of his two predecessors, and an [[internationalization]] policy called ''Segyehwa''. ==Early life and education== Kim was born in [[Geoje Island]], by the southeastern tip of the Korean peninsula, to a rich fishing family on 20 December 1927, when [[Korea under Japanese rule|Korea was under Imperial Japanese rule]]. He was the eldest of one son and five daughters in his family.{{cite web|url=http://biography.yourdictionary.com/kim-young-sam|title=Kim Young Sam Facts|publisher=Encyclopedia of World Biography|accessdate=12 November 2015}} During the [[Korean War]], Kim served in the [[Republic of Korea Armed Forces|South Korean military]] as a student soldier (or [[Officer candidate]]). In 1952, he graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[Philosophy]] from [[Seoul National University]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2015/11/21/world/asia/ap-as-skorea-obit-kim.html?_r=0|title=Hospital Official: Ex-SKorean President Kim Young-Sam Dies|work=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=21 November 2015}} ==Career== In 1954, Kim was elected to the [[National Assembly of South Korea]], as a member of the party led by [[Syngman Rhee]], the first president of South Korea. At the time of his election, Kim was the youngest member of the national assembly.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/hospital-official-skorean-president-kim-young-sam-dies-35345735|title=Former South Korean President Kim Young-Sam Dies at 87|publisher=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=21 November 2015}} A few months after his electoral victory, Kim left his party and joined the opposition when Rhee attempted to amend the [[constitution of South Korea]]. Kim then became a leading critic, along with [[Kim Dae-jung]], of the military governments of [[Park Chung-hee]] and [[Chun Doo-hwan]]. ===New Democratic Party leader=== In 1974, he was elected as the president of the [[New Democratic Party (South Korea)|New Democratic Party]]. While he temporarily lost his power within the national assembly in 1976, Kim made a political comeback during the final year of Park Chung-hee's rule. Kim took a hardline policy of never compromising or cooperating with Park's [[Democratic Republican Party (South Korea)|Democratic Republican Party]] until the [[Yushin Constitution]] was repealed and boldly criticized Park's dictatorship, which could be punished with imprisonment under the new constitution.{{cite news|last1=Breen |first1=Michael |title=Kim Young-sam: the man who would be president |url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/issues/2014/03/363_96977.html |accessdate=22 November 2015 |work=[[The Korea Times]] |date=19 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151122124301/http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/issues/2014/03/363_96977.html |archivedate=22 November 2015 |df= }} In August 1979, Kim allowed around 200 female workers at the Y.H. Trading Company to use the headquarters of New Democratic Party as a place for their sit-in demonstration and pledged to protect them. One thousand policemen raided the party headquarters and arrested the workers.{{cite book|last1=Lee|first1=Kenneth B.|title=Korea and East Asia: The Story of a Phoenix|date=1997|publisher=Praeger|location=Westport, Conn.|isbn=027595823X|page=196}} One female worker died in the process and many lawmakers trying to protect them were severely beaten, some requiring hospitalization. The [[Minjung#YH Company protest|YH Incident]] garnered widespread criticism and led to Kim's condemnation, with an assertion that Park's dictatorship would soon collapse.{{cite journal|last1=Fowler|first1=James|title=The United States and South Korean Democratization|journal=[[Political Science Quarterly]]|date=June 1999|volume=114|issue=2|pages=265–288|doi=10.2307/2657739|url=http://fowler.ucsd.edu/south_korea.pdf}} After this incident, Park was determined to remove Kim from the political scene, like the imprisoned Kim Dae-jung, and instructed the [[Korean Central Intelligence Agency|South Korean Central Intelligence Agency]] (KCIA) to engineer such a move. In September 1979, a court order suspended Kim's presidency of the New Democratic Party.{{cite book|last1=Vogel|first1=Ezra F.|last2=Kim|first2=Byung-Kook|title=The Park Chung Hee Era: The Transformation of South Korea|date=2011|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, Mass.|isbn=0674058208|pages=166–167}} When Kim called on the United States to stop supporting Park's dictatorship in an interview with the ''[[New York Times]]'',{{cite book|last1=Seth|first1=Michael J.|title=A Concise History of Modern Korea: From the Late Nineteenth Century to the Present|date=2010|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|location=Lanham|isbn=0742567133|page=187}} Park wanted to have Kim imprisoned while the [[Jimmy Carter|Carter Administration]], concerned over increasing human right violations, issued a strong warning not to persecute members of the opposition party. When Kim was expelled from the National Assembly in October 1979, the United States recalled its ambassador back to [[Washington, D.C.]], and all 66 lawmakers of the New Democratic Party resigned from the National Assembly. When it became known that the South Korean government was planning to accept the resignations selectively, uprisings broke out in Kim's hometown of [[Busan|Pusan]]. It was the biggest demonstration since the Syngman Rhee presidency, and spread to nearby [[Masan]] and other cities, with students and citizens calling for an end to the dictatorship. The crisis was one of the causes for [[Park Chung-hee assassination|the assassination of Park Chung-hee]] on 26 October 1979 by KCIA Director [[Kim Jae-gyu]].{{cite news|last1=Breen |first1=Michael |title=Inner circle collapses: Kim Jae-gyu and Cha Ji-cheol |url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/issues/2015/11/363_104936.html |accessdate=22 November 2015 |work=[[The Korea Times]] |date=15 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151122130235/http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/issues/2015/11/363_104936.html |archivedate=22 November 2015 |df= }} ===House arrest=== The government's oppressive stance towards the opposition continued under Chun Doo-hwan, who seized power with a military coup on 12 December 1979. Kim Young-Sam was expelled from the National Assembly for his democratic activities and banned from politics from 1980 to 1985. In 1983, he undertook a 21-day hunger strike protesting the dictatorship of [[Chun Doo-hwan]].{{cite news|title=Former President Kim Young-sam dies at age 87|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20151122000004|accessdate=21 November 2015|work=[[The Korea Herald]]|date=21 November 2015}} ===Failed presidential run, 1987=== When the [[South Korean presidential election, 1987|first democratic presidential election was held in 1987]] after Chun's retirement, Kim Young-sam and Kim Dae-jung ran against each other, splitting the opposition vote and enabling ex-general [[Roh Tae-woo]], Chun's hand-picked successor, to win the election. This was also despite support from the first female presidential candidate, [[Hong Sook-ja]], who resigned her candidacy in order to support Kim.{{cite web|last1=Holley|first1=David|title=Kim Young Sam Gets Backing of Only Woman in Korea Race|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-12-06/news/mn-27127_1_kim-young-sam|date=6 December 1987|accessdate=24 November 2016}} In 1990, he unexpectedly merged his Democratic Reunification Party with Roh's ruling [[Democratic Justice Party]] to form the [[New Korea Party|Democratic Liberal Party]], now the [[Liberty Korea Party]]. ===Presidency (1993–98)=== As the candidate of the governing party, he defeated Kim Dae-jung in the [[South Korean presidential election, 1992|1992 presidential election]]. He was only the third civilian to hold the office, and the first since 1962. The Kim Young-sam administration attempted to reform the government and the economy. One of the first acts of his government was to start an anti-corruption campaign, which began at the very top, as Kim promised not to use political [[slush funds]]. Kim's government required government and military officials to publish their financial records, precipitating the resignation of several high-ranking officers and cabinet members. He had his two predecessors as president, Chun and Roh, arrested and indicted on charges of corruption and treason for their role in military coups, although they would be pardoned near the end of his term. Kim also granted amnesty to thousands of political prisoners, and removed the criminal convictions of pro-democracy protesters who had been arrested during the [[Gwangju massacre]] in the aftermath of the [[Coup d'état of December Twelfth]]. The anti-corruption campaign was also part of an attempt to reform the ''[[chaebol]]'', the large South Korean conglomerates which dominated the economy. However, Kim's anti-corruption message was damaged after his son was arrested for bribery and tax evasion related to the [[Hanbo scandal]]. In 1994, when American president [[Bill Clinton]] mulled over attacking [[Yongbyon Nuclear Scientific Research Center|Nyongbyon]], the centre of [[North Korean nuclear program|North Korea's nuclear program]], Kim advised him to back down to prevent renewal of fighting. Kim's new ministerial party, the DLP lost its narrow majority in the National Assembly in 1996. [[Kia Motors]] collapsed soon thereafter, setting off a chain of events which embroiled South Korea in the [[1997 Asian Financial Crisis]] during the last year of his presidency.{{cite book|last1=Kihl|first1=Young Whan|title=Transforming Korean Politics: Democracy, Reform, and Culture|date=2005|publisher=M.E. Sharpe|location=Armonk|isbn=0765614286|pages=102–142}} During the financial crisis, the collapse of Kia and other conglomerates led Kim to accept a $58 billion USD bailout from the [[International Monetary Fund]]. ==Later life and death== After his presidency, Kim travelled the world promoting democracy, and speaking at events such as ''Towards a Global Forum on New Democracies'' in [[Taiwan]] in January 2007. He died in [[Seoul National University Hospital]] on 22 November 2015, from [[heart failure]], at the age of 87.{{cite web | url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/kim-young-sam-south-korean-president-ended-years-of-military-rule/article27446059/ | title=Kim Young Sam: South Korean president ended years of military rule | publisher=[[Bloomberg News]] | work=[[The Globe and Mail]] | accessdate=26 November 2015 | author=Kim, Hyung-Jin}} On 26 November 2015, a televised state funeral was held for Kim at the [[National Assembly (South Korea)|National Assembly]] lawn, during which Prime Minister [[Hwang Kyo-ahn]] delivered the opening remarks.{{cite web | url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/c236ea7ace424a20953bd5985ebf59d4/s-koreans-mourn-ex-president-kim-state-funeral | title=S. Koreans mourn ex-President Kim in state funeral | publisher=[[Associated Press]] | date=26 November 2015 | accessdate=26 November 2015 | author=Kim Tong-hyung}} Later that day, Kim was buried in the [[Seoul National Cemetery]]. ==Personal life== Kim was a member of the Chunghyun [[Presbyterianism|Presbyterian Church]] and was fluent in [[Japanese language|Japanese]] and his native language, [[Korean language|Korean]]. He was married to [[Son Myung-soon]].[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=NewsLibrary&p_multi=BBAB&d_place=BBAB&p_theme=newslibrary2&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F99F54822596E7B&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM Yonhap news agency]. 10 March 1997. He was survived by his children, two sons and three daughters, as well as his five younger sisters.{{cite web|url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/nationworld/7/71/1120940/hospital-official-former-south-korean-president-kim-young-sam|title=Hospital official: Former South Korean President Kim Young-sam|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|accessdate=22 November 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} {{Wikiquote}} * [http://www.kysarchives.or.kr/ Kim Young-Sam Memorial Museum] {{Ko icon}} * [http://www.rokps.or.kr/profile_result_ok.asp?num=543 Kim Young-Sam, Hunjunghwe]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{Ko icon}} *{{C-SPAN|youngsamkim}} {{S-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box |before=[[Roh Tae-woo]] |title=[[President of South Korea]] |years=25 February 1993 – 25 February 1998 |after=[[Kim Dae-jung]]}} {{s-end}} {{Presidents of South Korea}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kim, Young-sam}} [[Category:Kim Young-sam| ]] [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:2015 deaths]] [[Category:People from Geoje]] [[Category:Civil rights activists]] [[Category:South Korean democracy activists]] [[Category:Presidents of South Korea]] [[Category:Korean religious leaders]] [[Category:Members of the National Assembly (South Korea)]] [[Category:Seoul National University alumni]] [[Category:South Korean Presbyterians]] [[Category:Liberal Party (South Korea) politicians]] [[Category:Democratic Party (South Korea) politicians]] [[Category:Liberty Korea Party politicians]] [[Category:Kyungnam High School alumni]]

{{for|the Welsh murder victim|Murder of Karen Price}} {{Infobox person |name=Little Miss Nobody |image=File:Little Miss Nobody NCMEC.jpg |image_caption=[[Forensic facial reconstruction]] of the decedent, created by the [[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]] |birth_name= |birth_date= 1951–1958 (approximate) |birth_place= |death_date={{circa}} July 17–24, 1960 (aged 2–9) |death_place= |death_cause= [[Determinism|Undetermined]]. Suspected [[homicide]]{{cite news|title=Can TV Solve Yavapai 'Little Miss Nobody' case?|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=MNNNGtAgD4EC&dat=19610810&printsec=frontpage&hl=en|accessdate=September 24, 2015|work=Prescott Evening Courier|date=August 10, 1961}} |nationality= |citizenship= |disappeared_status= {{Unidentified for|1960|07|31}} |other_names= |ethnicity= |body_discovered=July 31, 1960
[[Congress, Arizona]], United States |resting_place= Mountain View Cemetery, [[Prescott, Arizona|Prescott]], Arizona, United States |resting_place_coordinates = {{Coord|34.5621|N|112.4806|W|region:US-MS_type:landmark|display=inline}} (approximate) |known_for= Unidentified victim of homicide |height= {{height|ft=3|in=6|abbr=mos}} (approximate){{cite news|title=1960 Cold Case: 'Little Miss Nobody' |date=March 28, 2018 |url=https://www.prescottenews.com/index.php/news/current-news/item/31703-1960-cold-case-little-miss-nobody |publisher=Prescott News |accessdate=May 4, 2018}} |weight= {{convert|55|lb|kg}} (approximate) }} '''Little Miss Nobody''' is the name posthumously given to a young girl whose body was found in [[Congress, Arizona|Congress]], [[Yavapai County, Arizona|Yavapai County]], [[Arizona]] on July 31, 1960. Her body is estimated to have been discovered between one and two weeks of the date of her death. Due to the advanced state of [[decomposition]] of the child's remains, the specific [[cause of death|cause of her death]] has never been established, although it has always been considered to be a [[homicide]]. Furthermore, despite extensive local and national efforts to discover the identity of this child, her identity remains [[unidentified decedent|unknown]], and the case remains unsolved. This unidentified decedent became known as "Little Miss Nobody" after no family or friends came forward to either report her [[missing person|missing]], or to claim her body. Following recent advances in technology, a [[forensic facial reconstruction]] of ''Little Miss Nobody'' was released to the media in 2018 in renewed efforts to identify this unidentified [[child murder]] victim's remains. ==Discovery and examination== The partially buried body of a female child was found in Sand Wash Creek Bed on Old Alamo Road in [[Congress, Arizona]] on July 31, 1960.{{cite news|title=Unidentified Girl Buried|accessdate=September 24, 2015|work=The Free-Lance Star|date=August 11, 1960|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=9fRKRCJz75UC&dat=19600811&printsec=frontpage&hl=en}} Her body was discovered by a [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] schoolteacher named Russell Allen, who had been searching for rocks to decorate his garden, and was found buried in a sitting position, with her arms stretched outwards.{{cite news|title=Baby Doe Missed Her Chance at Life but Regained Name |date=November 10, 1996 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-11-10/news/mn-63244_1_baby-jane-doe |publisher=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=May 24, 2018}} Investigators at the scene observed that the individual or individuals responsible for the child's burial had possibly made two separate attempts to dig an alternate grave for her body. This was determined by two evident disturbances in the sand close to the actual burial site. The body was clothed in white shorts and a checkered blouse with a distinctive chain pattern, along with a pair of adult rubber thong [[sandal]]s that had been cut to fit the child's feet and fastened with leather straps.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 10741|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/10741|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=May 13, 2015|date=November 2, 2012}}{{cite news|title=Unidentified Body Found on Desert|accessdate=September 24, 2015|work=Prescott Evening Courier|date= August 1, 1960|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=MNNNGtAgD4EC&dat=19600801&printsec=frontpage&hl=en}} The child's toes and fingernails had reportedly been painted a bright red color. Investigators also found an apparently bloodstained pocket knife near the body, but were unable to definitively determine whether this utensil held any relation to the crime scene. The [[forensic pathology|forensic pathologist]] who performed the autopsy determined that the body was that of a [[Caucasian race|white]] girl between the ages of 5- and 7-years old,{{cite news|last1=DeHoff|first1=Faye|title=Trying to identify "Little Miss Nobody"|url=http://www.kvoa.com/story/37833294/trying-to-identify-little-miss-nobody|accessdate=31 March 2018|work=News 4 Tucson|agency=NBC|date=March 28, 2018}} 3 feet–6 inches to 4 feet–5 inches in height, and likely weighing 50 to 60 pounds (later examinations of the child's remains indicated she may have been as old as 9 or as young as 2 at the time of her death). The child had been deceased for between one and two weeks prior to the discovery of her remains.{{cite web|title=Case File: 1202UFAZ|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/1202ufaz.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=May 13, 2015|date=October 25, 2014}} Her hair color was brown, possibly having been tinted or dyed auburn,{{cite news|title=9 Murder Victims Whose Names Remain a Mystery|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/the-lineup/9-murder-victims-whose-na_b_8031378.html|accessdate=September 24, 2015|work=Huffington Post|date=August 25, 2015}} and she had a full set of intact [[deciduous teeth|milk teeth]] described as being in a markedly good condition. (Although the actual race of the decedent has since been described as being indeterminable, the highest likelihood of her actual age at the time of her death has since been determined as being 3 to 6 years.{{cite news|title='Little Miss Nobody' Buried by Community|accessdate=September 24, 2015|work=Rome News-Tribune|date=August 11, 1960|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=BJbdYPG6LGMC&dat=19600811&printsec=frontpage&hl=en}}{{cite news|title=Who is 'Little Miss Nobody'? What Authorities Want You to Know About Decomposed Girl Found in 1960 |date=April 5, 2018 |url=https://www.click2houston.com/news/who-is-little-miss-nobody-what-authorities-want-you-to-know-about-decomposed-girl-found-in-1960 |publisher=Click 2 Houston |accessdate=May 24, 2018}}) The actual [[cause of death]] of the decedent was never determined by [[medical examiner]]s, although her death was officially declared to be a homicide.''Someone's Daughter: In Search of Justice for Jane Doe'' {{ISBN|978-1-589-79420-7}} p. 200 Furthermore, the forensic pathologist was able to definitively state that she had not suffered any [[bone fracture]]s at the time of her death, or in her lifetime.{{cite news|title=Mendocino County Cold Case Identifications Made Nearly 37 Years Later |date=March 28, 2018 |url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/arizona/2018/03/28/little-miss-nobody-sheriffs-office-hopes-image-helps-solve-58-year-old-case/467973002/ |publisher=Arizona Central |accessdate=May 12, 2012}} In addition, the contemporary report pertaining to the child's autopsy indicates her remains were charred, presumably from her body having been set alight around the time of her death.{{cite web|last1=Lee|first1=Jaime|title=Little Miss Nobody|url=http://blog.jaimegipe.com/2011/03/little-miss-nobody/|accessdate=December 27, 2015|date=March 23, 2011}} Because the decedent had been in an advanced state of decomposition at the time of her discovery, creating an actual [[facial composite|composite drawing]] of the child's facial features was not possible.{{refn|group=n|Contemporary records retained at the [[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]] state the child's face had actually been in a "recognizable" state at the time of her discovery.}} ===Initial investigations=== With active assistance from the local media, private citizens, and (later) assistance from officials as eminent as individuals within the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]], the Yavapai County sheriff's office worked tirelessly in their efforts to discover the decedent's identity. An [[all-points bulletin]] was initially broadcast across all sheriff radio and [[teletype]] networks following the discovery of this child's body,{{cite news|title=Clue to 'Little Miss Nobody' Still Sought |date=November 4, 1960 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=897&dat=19601104&id=BhxPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZE8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6557%2C19 |publisher=Prescott Evening Courier |accessdate=February 26, 2018}} and Yavapai County Sheriff Jim Cramer, Deputy County Attorney George Ireland and other local law enforcement personnel would subsequently travel hundreds of miles in radius via both air and land in their efforts to discover her identity. Individuals previously convicted of various offenses involving young children would be subjected to prolonged interrogations, and the sheriff's office also received dozens of letters, telephone calls, and telegrams in response to their public appeals for information in their efforts to discover the child's identity. Furthermore, any possibility the decedent had been any known missing young girl was investigated, and discounted.{{refn|group=n|Investigators initially speculated that this decedent may have hailed from an [[Poverty|impoverished]] background, and/or have been the child of migrants, although all investigative lines of inquiry into these theories failed to bear fruition.}} [[File:LMN sandals.jpg|thumb|right|The sandals worn by the decedent]] By August 1960, investigators began to suspect the remains may have been those of a four-year-old girl named Sharon Lee Gallegos, who had been abducted in [[New Mexico]] ten days before the discovery of the child's body. Despite the fact that the clothing the victim wore was inconsistent to that Gallegos was last seen wearing, they could not eliminate Gallegos as being the decedent due to this fact, as the clothing could have easily been changed in the intervening week.{{cite news |title=Officers Still Seek Clues {{not a typo|T}}o Identify Body of Girl: Missing Girl in N.M. May Be New Lead |accessdate=August 21, 2018 |work=Prescott Evening Courier |date=August 2, 1960 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xxRPAAAAIBAJ&pg=5939,1407220 |volume=LXXVIII |number=150}} Gallegos currently remains a [[missing person]].{{cite web |title=3683DFNM - Sharon Lee Gallegos |url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/3683dfnm.html |website=[[The Doe Network]] |accessdate=August 21, 2018 |date=February 4, 2017}} However, police later released a statement that they believed the unidentified child was older than Gallegos.{{cite news |title=New Lead is No Help in Learning Identity of Little Girl's Body |work=Prescott Evening Courier |date=August 3, 1960}} Initial speculation that the child may have been a member of a family of transients, also from New Mexico. Police also subjected one Lester Davidson and two of his four children to in excess of an hour of questioning. Davidson and his children had been known to have been hitchhiking near [[Prescott, Arizona|Prescott]] in late July 1960. This questioning concluded that the family likely had no connection to either the unidentified child or Sharon Gallegos. Following the verification of the Davidsons' [[alibi]]s, police sent the clothing, knife, and footprints found with or near the child's body to an [[FBI]] laboratory to undergo further examination.{{cite news |title=Footprints may lead to body ID |work=Prescott Evening Courier |date=August 5, 1960}} In March 1961, a possibility arose that the decedent may have been one Debbie Dudley; a four-year-old girl missing from [[Virginia]]. Investigators had failed to find the bodies of Dudley and her remaining siblings after the body of her seven-year-old sister, Carol Ann, was found wrapped in a blanket on February 9, 1961, she having died due to a combination of the [[malnutrition]], [[Infant exposure|exposure]], and [[Child neglect|neglect]] she had endured from her parents.{{cite news|title=Little Miss: She's 'God's Little Child'|location=Milwaukee, Wisconsin|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1368&dat=19610302&id=L29QAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gREEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3348,708824&hl=en|accessdate=December 27, 2015|work=The Milwaukee Sentinel|date=March 2, 1961|page=20}} Debbie's remains were later found in [[Southern Virginia]]. She was later interred alongside her sister. The parents of the sisters were later charged with both murders.{{cite news|title=Debbie to Be Buried Beside Sister|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1876&dat=19610316&id=-3ksAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1ssEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1343,1944727&hl=en|accessdate=December 27, 2015|work=The Spartanburg Herald|agency=Herald-Journal|date=March 16, 1961|location=Spartanburg, South Carolina}} On August 8, 1961, Sheriff Cramer led a party of law enforcement officers and a camera crew to film the location where the child's body had been found. Later that afternoon, Sheriff Cramer and Yavapai County Attorney George Ireland presented evidence—including the adult-sized rubber sandals which had been purposely cut to fit the child's feet—to the media, with Sheriff Cramer stating: "Somewhere, there is someone who has the answer that we have been looking for; maybe this will be the thing that will bring that person forward." The footage of this scene and the interview with Sheriff Cramer was later broadcast on television in the hope fresh leads toward establishing the identity of the child would ensue, although the program brought no significant new information. Despite the numerous and extensive local and national efforts conducted to identify the decedent, all contemporary efforts to either identify the child, or trace any of her relatives, failed. {{external media | align = left | width = | image1 = [https://images.findagrave.com/photos/2012/298/99600514_135121895717.jpg The grave of ''Little Miss Nobody'' at Mountain View Cemetery] }} ==Funeral== The funeral of this unidentified child was conducted on August 10, 1960. She was laid to rest in Mountain View Cemetery, with the campaign for funds to provide a dignified burial—as opposed to anonymous interment inside a [[pauper's grave]]—being spearheaded by a local radio announcer named Dave Palladin, who successfully initiated a fundraising and donations appeal to local businesses, funeral homes and residents to ensure the child received a respectful burial. Palladin referred to his primary motivation for this fundraising campaign as being that he found the thought of a "little girl buried in [[Boot Hill]]"{{cite news|title="Little Miss Nobody" Buried as Somebody|accessdate=September 24, 2015|work=The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|date=March 2, 1961|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1368&dat=19610302&id=L29QAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gREEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2034,505900&hl=en}} as an insufferable one, adding of his insistence the child received a decent [[Christian burial]].{{cite news|title=Clue to 'Little Miss Nobody' Still Sought |date=November 4, 1960 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=897&dat=19601104&id=BhxPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZE8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6557,190483 |publisher=Prescott Evening Courier |accessdate=May 14, 2018}} Prior to her funeral, the child had become colloquially known within and around Yavapai County as "Little Miss Nobody".{{cite news|title= 1960 Cold Case: 'Little Miss Nobody' |date=March 25, 2018 |url=https://www.prescottenews.com/index.php/news/current-news/item/31703-1960-cold-case-little-miss-nobody |publisher=Prescott News |accessdate=May 15, 2018}} The funeral service for Little Miss Nobody was conducted at the Congregational Church in [[Prescott, Arizona]], and was officiated by Dr. Charles Franklin Parker, with over 70 mourners in attendance. At this service, a placard was placed upon Little Miss Nobody's pale blue casket, with the inscription reading: "God's little child, date of birth unknown, date of death unknown."{{refn|group=n|Among the several messages of condolence for Little Miss Nobody placed among the floral arrangements around her casket, one anonymous writer had written a note stating: 'Forgive us, child, for the weakness of men and, in turn, when in your final home, pray for us.'''Someone's Daughter: In Search of Justice for Jane Doe'' {{ISBN|978-1-589-79420-7}} pp. 200-201}} Her headstone is inscribed with a section of a quote from [[Matthew the Apostle|St. Matthew]], which reads, "Blessed are the Pure in Heart."{{cite news|title='Little Miss Nobody': Sheriff's Office Hopes Image Helps Solve 58-year-old Case |date=March 28, 2018 |url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/arizona/2018/03/28/little-miss-nobody-sheriffs-office-hopes-image-helps-solve-58-year-old-case/467973002/ |publisher=Arizona Central |accessdate=May 8, 2018}} During the [[eulogy]] at the funeral of Little Miss Nobody, Dr. Parker recited a poem entitled "For a Little Girl Unknown"''The Long Term Missing: Hope and Help for Families'' {{ISBN|978-1-442-25680-4}} p. 188 before addressing those in attendance with a speech in which he stated: "Here is a little wanderer who has been in our midst. We don't know her name; we can only guess her age. It occurs to me we may not know, but God knows. There are no unknowns, no orphans in God's world. ... She doesn't need a name today. She has the name of an angel somewhere in eternity''The Long Term Missing: Hope and Help for Families'' {{ISBN|978-1-442-25680-4}} p. 188 ... we may never know the why's and wherefores, but, somewhere, someone is going to be watching the paper to learn what happened to a little girl left on the desert. If there has been a misdeed, probably a disquieted [[conscience]] will go on and on."''Someone's Daughter: In Search of Justice for Jane Doe'' {{ISBN|978-1-589-79420-7}} p. 200{{refn|group=n|Within the [[eulogy]] he recited at the funeral for Little Miss Nobody, Dr. Parker predicted that the identity of this child would never be known.{{cite news|title=''Little Miss Nobody': Sheriff's Office Hopes Image Helps Solve 58-year-old Case |date=March 29, 2018 |url=https://eu.azcentral.com/story/news/local/arizona/2018/03/28/little-miss-nobody-sheriffs-office-hopes-image-helps-solve-58-year-old-case/467973002/ |publisher=Arizona Central |accessdate=May 25, 2018}}}} {{quote box | quote = "Any detail, no matter how small [it may seem], is important in the quest to determine this child’s identity." |source = [[Yavapai County, Arizona|Yavapai County]] Sheriff's Office, addressing the media following the release of the [[facial composite|composite drawing]] of how Little Miss Nobody may have looked in life. March 2018.{{cite news|title=''Little Miss Nobody': Sheriff's Office Hopes Image Helps Solve 58-year-old Case |date=March 29, 2018 |url=https://eu.azcentral.com/story/news/local/arizona/2018/03/28/little-miss-nobody-sheriffs-office-hopes-image-helps-solve-58-year-old-case/467973002/ |publisher=Arizona Central |accessdate=May 25, 2018}} | width = 30em }} ==Ongoing investigation== Due to recent advances in technology and [[DNA profiling]],{{cite news|title=Cold case: YCSO Continues to Seek Identity of Child's Skeletal Remains, aka the 'Little Miss Nobody Case' |date=March 30, 2018 |url=https://www.dcourier.com/news/2018/mar/30/cold-case-ycso-continues-seek-identity-childs-skel/ |publisher=The Daily Courier |accessdate=June 5, 2018}} a decision to [[Burial#Exhumation|exhume]] the body of Little Miss Nobody to obtain a [[Genetic testing|DNA sample]] was made in 2018,{{cite news|title=Investigators Reopen 50-year-old 'Little Miss Nobody' Case |date=April 6, 2018 |url=http://www.tucsonnewsnow.com/story/37896707/investigators-reopen-50-year-old-little-miss-nobody-case |publisher=Tucson News |accessdate=May 22, 2018}} with The [[National Center for Missing and Exploited Children]] offering to pay for the exhumation and required testing. Resultingly, samples of the girl's DNA were successfully obtained from her body, and entered into both the [[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]] and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children databases for comparison with nationwide unsolved murders and missing person reports. Furthermore, the [[University of North Texas Center for Human Identification]] also created a detailed [[forensic facial reconstruction]] of the decedent, depicting how she may have appeared in life, before her body was reburied at Mountain View Cemetery.{{cite news|title=1960 Cold Case: Little Miss Nobody |date=March 28, 2018
